title: Sustainable Growth: Building Studios Without External Funding

rawLines.text: [Music]
welcome to the Navit Gaming Podcast
where it is our mission to explore the
business and future of video games we
bring together the industry's brightest
builders investors and thinkers to keep
a pulse on current events dissect
emerging trends and games share lessons
learned and have a great time
this podcast is also part of Navik's
growing ecosystem which ranges from free
and premium research to consulting and
advisory services for more information
visit
[Music]
www.navic.co this episode is brought to
you by AWS for games aws for games
aligns purpose-built game development
capabilities including AWS services like
Amazon GameLift as well as solutions
from AWS partners to help game
developers build run and grow their
games these solutions simplify how you
use AWS making it easier to select the
right tools for your desired use case
this reduces the time and investment
required for game developers to adopt
the cloud leaving more time to innovate
and achieve faster time to value aws
brings over 15 years of experience
supporting transformation for game
developers including Riot Games Scoply
Second Dinner Behavior Interactive and
Nintendo with hundreds of millions
playing games built on AWS for games
thousands of AWS partners and teams of
AWS solutions architects around the
world your game is in good hands within
the AWS community for more information
visit
aws.amazon.com/gametech or simply check
out the link in the show notes now let's
jump into the episode what's up everyone
and uh welcome to the Novak Gaming
Podcast i'm your host Alex and this is
our interview and insight segment um but
if we sound a little bit different today
it's because today's conversation is
extra special um we are my guests and I
and several amazing audience members are
here live in San Francisco um in March
yeah um casting in from the Hathora Hub
um shout out to those guys to Gabby
specifically um thank you so much for
organizing all the logistics the mic
crew um the cameras it's honestly been a
tremendous amount of effort and an
amazing opportunity for us at Novvic to
do our first ever live audience show and
thank you to the audience for being here
i know GDC is a very busy schedule we
have lots of conflicts and so I'm
honored that you decided to join um Nick
and I today uh we're going to drink
straight from the fire hose so I'm
looking kind of nervous to be honest um
I've never done a live show before but
um my guest Nick has spoken at GDC
multiple times and so Nick how are you
feeling this uh lovely afternoon uh this
this would be a great time for me to
like stammer and not know how to speak
in public after that intro um I'm doing
I'm doing great uh thank you very much
it's it's always great to to come down
to GDC and you know have these
conversations with the same group of
people that happen once a year or twice
a year um it almost feels like you're
like writing letters to people um back
in the old days uh so yeah it's a lot of
fun yeah that's terrific yeah I think
GDC is such a great place for the
industry to come together um and you're
so seasoned at GDC and so I kind of feel
privileged to be sitting with you here
today um and I'm exuberant to have a
conversation about what I think people
think is the epitome of studio
foundership um and to set some context
uh Nick is a founder of a very
successful indie studio he's spoken at
GDC multiple times he founded Manomi
Park in 2014 um and their debut IP Slime
Rancher um sold 10 million units on
Steam um woo uh Slime Rancher 2 which
came out in 2022 sold around 1.6 million
units and the franchise has over 20
million players wow we should give that
definitely a
furra most of this entirely DIY um no
external financing from Venture um no
publishers no VC no crowd financing no
marketing support and very few or to
none peripheral external development i
think you said at some point you had
some support on physical disc
distribution um yeah yeah we we
partnered with uh Skybound for Xbox One
and and PS4 distribution yeah yeah but
in in suff in suffice to say um you know
in a market today where funding is
retreating as VCs realize that the asset
class might not be worth the squeeze and
publishers are kind of recalcitrant to
bet on anything new i find our
conversation to be pretty timely and
topical um and so we're going to get
right into it um we're going to be doing
around a 45minut conversation and
fireside style and then we're going to
open it up to audience Q&A so start
thinking about some questions that you
might want to ask Nick um and let's roll
so the first thing I'd like to do is
we're going to go through a brief
history of Manomi Park um take me back
to 2014 who Who are you then and why did
you start a video game studio um well
the person I was at that time was was
very tired um I had worked for about 10
years making MMOs um at a company called
Three Rings Design um they are wonderful
and uh I owe my entire career to to
those folks um and uh one of the OG
indie developers like making indie games
uh at a at a a a bigger scale um in 2000
you know when there was like four people
doing that so it was a it was a real
privilege to be a part of that and uh I
got to see you know kind of how the
sausage was made and uh I'm one of those
um like space aliens that knew what they
wanted to do when they were five and
like stuck with it and so it was always
in my head that I was going to start a
game company and so I I I'm led
development of a game called Spiral
Nights there uh Sega was going to
publish us then they bought us and uh
then I knew it was time to to to go when
it was time to make another game and so
it was just that that was it it was like
a foregone conclusion it wasn't uh
really a confluence of things i just um
I just left uh the company and started
my own thing
and uh so you said you were you were you
were very you were very stressed then um
and you but you knew what you wanted to
do you wanted to start a game studio
since you were five um I'm curious did
you start it with Founders and who did
you start Monomi Park with yeah so uh
what first happened was I watched
Netflix for 2 weeks cuz I hadn't taken a
vacation in 10 years um and uh and then
I really Googled how to make a game in
Unity um what what we had been doing at
Three Rings was all in-house tools and
so um I didn't I I knew how to make
games and I had a taste that I had
developed um but I uh I did not know how
to code i come from an art background um
so I just cobbled some scripts together
and got the idea for Slime Rancher and
presented it to the other co-founder of
uh Monami Park uh Mike Thomas who I uh
coerced into joining me and uh then we
began the company that summer officially
yeah um and uh what what was his
background uh he's an engineer uh so you
guys were a good duo together yeah we we
worked alongside each other for almost
10 years but not really ever together
but we uh walked to and from the train
Cal Train uh right down the street we
walked to and from there for like 9 or
10 years so I got to know him really
well you know as a person got it yeah
yeah and I think actually one of the
most interesting things that you shared
with me um when we were chatting and
prospecting and seeing whether or not
this episode could come together um was
your slow growth model to scaling this
studio so over the course of 10 years
you grew from two people you and that
co-founder to 45 most studios do this
sometimes today in three months um walk
me through your approach to growth um
specifically how did you know uh growing
the team was necessary and how did it
change over time yeah uh so a note about
the 45 people even uh you know a a lot
of that is fairly recent so we shipped
Slime Rancher 2 in 2022
uh with like probably around 22 23
people so we've we've grown a little bit
since then um but really uh I at Three
Rings I learned how you just grow slowly
and you you like we we made an MMO that
Spiral Nights game I mentioned was like
a team of like seven at its core and you
know we were competing for like MMO of
the year and everything else like like
the best of them so you can do it um but
in terms of how we grew slowly um it was
basically a commitment to stay as small
as possible for as long as possible and
uh reach a I call it kind of like a
requisite pain threshold before you're
willing to hire for something so you're
doing that thing and you want to stop
doing that thing or you want to be able
to delegate it and you just keep doing
that thing until it's so painful you say
"All right no this is definitely there's
there's a job here for that." Yeah i I
kind of want to dig a little bit deeper
there because there's this phrase that
says like you know you want a staff you
want a staff to trough not staff to peak
um and you want your team to flex to
peak um when you say and it's so painful
what is describe a little bit more about
what that might mean because I think
that for maybe a lot of people who want
to start their own studio here or
currently entrepreneurs you know that
what is the appropriate level of pain
threshold how long that should that be
going on for because you know for some
people it just might be like oh my god
I've been so overwhelmed for a month or
two definitely need an extra headcount
so what was that for you guys yeah so I
I think there's a difference between um
something being painful in your work and
something that's like bleeding you out
you know if you're spending half of the
time doing your social media or whatever
uh then that that that is a job that
should be done if if it is just
something that is annoying um you know
bringing someone on board at least in
the old days uh having them move across
the country potentially and like change
their life for this job that you've
carved out um that's a huge
responsibility for you the person who's
hiring them like at Monami Park we
always say like this is going to sound a
little creepy but we don't mean it this
way is that we hire for life um we're we
don't um expect anyone to stay with us
forever but on our end it is our
responsibility to make sure that they
have a job forever so long as they're
doing their job and everyone's happy um
so that's one of the reasons for the
slow growth is like you have to figure
out how this person fits forever and
then additionally you have to adapt to
all of the sudden there's new appendage
on this monster and so you don't want to
have too many of those at once you know
you have to you have to go slowly and
integrate them into your company culture
and make them ultimately like an
advocate for your company so when you
bring on the next person that process is
smoother that's really interesting um
and I guess like you know to that point
of this is a job monomi Park is a job
forever um and you actually mentioned
this example of I'm spending 50% of my
time doing social media that might be a
job that someone else should do um you
know you're a team of around 45 now i'm
curious what percent of the team today
are direct developers um and how
especially did you know when was the
right time to spend capital on a
non-development head um when a lot of
times at a studio that stuff that so
social media or finance or partnerships
might just get distributed amongst the
developers themselves um well uh I think
we have a perspective at our studio um
and perhaps this is being ignorant but
like everyone's a developer like as far
as I'm concerned everybody at the studio
is a developer everyone gets in the
credits like everyone's doing something
that is allowing in our case Slime
Rancher to exist so um a job is a job if
there if if it's necessary for the
company to run that office management is
a thing or uh you know customer service
folks or or it doesn't whatever uh that
is necessary for us to function as a
studio so they're part of it um there is
no sort of separation at at our studio
anyway um so it it it becomes um that's
not even like really to make a point so
much as like it becomes much easier to
think about adding people to your
company in that way um versus uh trying
to determine like how how much um of a
force multiplier they're going to be at
at the end of the day how many commits
are made or something like that like
that that's that you're I feel like
that's that's almost like a little too
clinical you have to you have to think
that anybody that you're bringing on
board is solving a problem for you
because it was painful a moment ago you
know there's that pain threshold so
they're they're they're doing their part
and they're they're part of what makes
this ship keep going so I see okay so
for you I mean obviously a lot of big
gaming companies you very much think of
it as like your game development team
and then you have SGNA um and for you
guys you don't think about it that way
at all everybody is core to the product
um and I really like that vision i think
it's um also you know probably lends
itself to building a very strong studio
culture and so can you tell me a little
bit about actually how the studio worked
together every day you know you told me
that you're you launched Slime Rancher
one with around like maybe somewhere
like 23 people or something like that
slime Rancher one oh no slime Rancher
one we launched with two people slime
Rancher one you launched with two people
okay never mind um and then Slime
Rancher 2 you launched with 23 people
right um for the development process of
this game um how can you tell me a
little bit about how the studio worked
together um one of the things you
mentioned to me was that you guys never
crunched and I think that's a pretty
rare thing in game development to never
crunch um how did you guys successfully
avoid crunch
um well so crunch being this like you
know sustained over time and it's
enforced and that sort of thing like yes
we've we've never done anything like
that um and I think one of the reasons
is we never did from the beginning so
when Mike and I founded the company we
were getting some art support from our
friend who was our first hire after we
shipped um we didn't crunch either we
worked we shipped Slime Rancher in 18
months uh from the beginning working 9
to5 or or 10 to 6 really um and uh he
would just show up at my apartment and
we'd go in the spare bedroom and work
and we'd take lunch together and like
watch Netflix and we'd get back to work
and we just had a very normal life um
and so my point is that it's really hard
to change once you've created some
muscle memory in your company so I think
it's pretty normal to say we're going to
be a scrappy startup and for now we're
just going to hire all our friends who
look like us and then later once we have
money then then we'll diversify and uh
right now we're going to work our asses
off but it's just till the product ships
and then suddenly we're going to stop
behaving the way that we've been
behaving for 2 or 3 years you know like
that's really difficult to do it's
ingrained in your culture at that point
so we wanted to make sure that the
expectation at our studio is you know
there is no overlord telling you this
has to get done figure it out like we'll
figure that out um it makes it very
difficult though because you have
exactly like one dial that you can turn
when things aren't working out after
you've like cut down to phone and that's
just to delay and that's it that's all
you can do like development almost
becomes kind of boring in that way from
like a strategic standpoint because
there's very little that you can do
overall i see that's definitely an
interesting and very different approach
I would say than because I think a lot
of times you there is that strategic
forcing function we need to ship in Q3
of 2020X because if we don't make that
date then perilous things will happen
afterwards or if we're too early
perilous things will happen in the
beginning um and so it's an interesting
approach of the preservation of your
guys' culture which is how you were how
you started that kind of creates that
environment such that you're never going
to bend that rule because that's just
the way that you started um I found it
really interesting that you kind of
mentioned that malleability about only
till then and then we'll change um
definitely something to think about from
the from the game development side and
if you're ever starting a studio um the
foundation that you kind of start with
um but I kind of want to shift gears a
little bit um thank you for sharing a
little bit about Monomi Parks Foundation
um the team the studio the culture um
but I want to talk about launching your
very first game so Slime Rancher 1 I
believe launched in 2016 um it's your
first title and you're sitting there in
2016 and this entire time you've been
doing stuff on your own and I'm curious
did you ever think about finding a
partner for distribution
um no uh we knew that we had enough to
you know ship it comfortably um we had
uh both of us um had savings and we um
felt like if we were going to do
something I think partly because we had
come from a company that was independent
for you know a very long time um we felt
like it would be most valuable if we
owned everything whatever art that we're
creating that that's ours um it wasn't
until after we had it that we then
started looking at like games with gold
stuff and the sort of opportunities that
you get once you have a game but um we
were pretty uh pretty fixed on the idea
of um you know just doing ourselves and
I think partly is um for almost all of
my career I never had that experience so
I I didn't even know how to work with a
publisher i still don't but uh uh so it
it just seemed very foreign to me like
that that uh you would do that and I
totally understand why folks do that but
at the same reason that like I was
originally using the Mac or the PC that
I was using it's just what you were used
to you know so um I think that's that's
where all of that came from and we
wanted to stay independent yeah and you
also mentioned something pretty funny
the other day when you said I think
quote I had never worked with a partner
that was a force multiplier um end quote
uh which I think obviously also kind of
sets your it sets your expectations for
what you're what you might be getting
out of partner um and you know so okay
so you decided you don't want to work
with anybody and in 2019 at GDC you did
a talk called um making games that stand
out and survive and your punchline of
that talk was something like getting
people to notice your game buy it and
play it repeatedly um and so in a few
maybe brief words uh can you give the
highlevel points that you made um in
that talk that for teams that want to
accomplish this and how you applied that
to Slime Rancher one especially given
that you were independent yeah sure so I
think um obviously things change rapidly
and so I don't even know how much of of
those talks are relevant but I know that
some of it still is uh certainly um the
idea that uh I know it seems very basic
but like that someone sees your game and
wants to play it at the end of the day
and like uh to unpack that a little bit
uh they're seeing something that that
catches their attention in some form but
most importantly they feel like there is
more to it than what they are seeing
there and they want to engage with it to
find that out so I think a lot of times
I see and in in this talk it was about
like basically think about your game as
a GIF um which is not giving audio its
due but just assume someone's looking at
it on social and they don't have audio
on um it's seeing can you encapsulate
your game in a such a short form that it
does those things and someone still
wants to engage with it and I should say
and I should have said this at the top
of everything this is specifically how I
make games this is not like how everyone
makes games i have some very successful
friends that would never follow my any
of my advice because their games just
don't function that way that's awesome i
only have my own experience to offer up
here but I tend to make games that are
kind of Nintendo um I like to think we
make at Monami Park Nintendo-like things
on PC um as a starting point and so
having something that uh teases the the
viewer and demands more is great um I
was saying earlier like I see a lot of
uh really wonderful uh indie games all
the time that you you you go oh my gosh
that's such an inventive mechanic and
then you watch like 10 seconds of it and
you're like what else is there to it and
that's so unfair but that's what
everyone's doing you know like so you
have to there has to be something about
it it couldn't even be the presentation
of it it's this thing that is
interesting and it's got unexpectedly a
gothic horror presentation or something
you go "Well I need to know what that's
all about." Like if you remember seeing
Inscription for the first time if that
was presented as like a a cold sort of
deck of cards in front of you and had
none of that backdrop you'd go "Okay
well it's a some sort of deck builder
game or something like that." But there
was just so much more immediately it it
created a mythology to the viewer and I
think that's that's what made it such a
hit or one of the reasons anyway
yeah I think you had mentioned like
trying to get your game into a 50 to 30
second gif um to kind of capture and and
bring in the player right and then after
that you know there's this phase okay
I've noticed the game but how do I get
them to play it um and so sorry I
skipped I skipped a beat how do you get
them to buy it and then how do you get
them to play it repeatedly um can you
walk us through some of your thought
process around those two pillars yeah I
mean how how you get them to buy it uh
you know that's tough uh um I think I
think uh I don't even know if I I
outlined so much of of that in the talk
of um you know the the how you then get
them to transact um but obviously point
them towards the the store that it's on
um or point them towards a wish list my
god like uh Indies have links to a wish
list in a store page in the like tweet
or whatever it was that's like doing the
numbers the follow-up reply that's like
"Oh by the way if you could be so kind
please wishlist it." Like no one sees
that so like give them uh an action item
um but how you get them to keep playing
it and again not every game is going to
do this but can you uh have an
environment in your game i don't it
doesn't even need to be literally an
environment but some sort of platform
within it where you can kind of rest and
re-engage with the game at a higher
level so like you're you're returning I
call it home um but you're returning
back to this sort of lower stakes but
still rewarding aspect of the game um
and there's a bunch of different
examples across a bunch of different
games that do that but it's if you think
about a player like oscillating their
experience between high risk and high
investment and then relax and then high
risk and high investment and then relax
it could be the boss fight it whatever
it is um you have to like dump them back
into some place that isn't Netflix or
their phone or something um you have to
let them stay in the game uh and this
isn't anything creepy like you're this
isn't so they can do microtransactions
and everything this is just so they're
still playing your game and they might
finish it and they might review it
positively because people that do that
tend to review it more positively so
you're just trying to foster um a more
emotionally positive relationship with
your customer by doing that okay so you
talked about these couple of principles
um for Slime Rancher one specifically um
how did you tie up these tactics
um like kind of operationally right so
like for Slime Rancher one what was the
15 to 30 second gift for Slime Rancher
one what was the team needs a pulse to
survive what was the unique home
friction kills yeah so the um the gift
was easy uh nothing at the time looked
like Slime Rancher um and the other
decision that we made so with Slime
Rancher part of the fun of the design
was um every time I like to make a game
it's stuff that I've never done before
um I never made a first-p person shooter
never made a farming game i don't really
like farming games that much uh never
done anything weird with physics all
that so it was like it was a fun
challenge but we knew that social was a
thing streaming was a thing all of that
so um Slime Rancher is an inverse first
person shooter um in a in a first-person
shooter you're looking at a subset of
the screen as information travels away
from the viewplane and you're tracking
that information uh Slime Rancher it's
in reverse so information is traveling
towards the screen and it's getting
bigger and brighter and more friendly to
things like social um and so then uh uh
the next part was um uh keeping them in
the game uh Slime Rancher never really
stops you just it's just a platform for
which you can continue to do the thing
at at your your your leisure um and so
uh one of the reasons that was fun was I
had just come from MMOs where you're
trying to hold on to customers in very
specific ways and you're trying to get
them to always reach for the next thing
and the next thing and the next thing
and in Slime Rancher we just put all the
things out there in front of you and
said "Go get them we're not really
particularly going to stop you from
doing it there's no like invisible walls
or anything like that." It was like
completely liberating to do that um and
then what was the last part i'm sorry ah
the the friction kills you need a home
yeah yeah so Slime Rancher is almost
like pure home um anytime you want you
can stop doing what you're doing the
game will not punish you and you can
just go do something else and I love
that um so anymore for me at least it's
um the highest level of friction in
games is for me is when agency is taken
away from me um so I don't like I don't
like cut scenes that all of a sudden
happen out of nowhere and everything
like I I don't like tutorials that are
telling me like I can only do this
limited subset of of actions right now
so um Slime Ranchers tutorial Ser's
tutorial is like 15 seconds long or
something like that suffice to say
you're not playing any JRPGs yeah I used
to love them uh and I every time I try
and play one now I I can't I can't take
it unfortunately um and it's it has
everything to do with my lack of
patience uh as uh the person I am and
nothing to do with the quality of those
games but I'm just a different person
now um so yeah like Slime Rancher
basically lets you uh exist in its world
and just be and things will keep
happening so it it doesn't like the
world doesn't revolve around you um the
world just keeps happening so even if
you do stop um stuff will pop out of the
environment and little dramas will play
out and that's really important um
because we've found especially with two
people just like to be in the world and
we've invested a lot in features that
support that particular behavior i see
yeah these like small tidbits of delight
of walking around the world and
something just exciting happens um but
okay so Slime Rancher you've done all
these things you know to get people to
buy it to get people to notice it um you
know it's you said it's visually nothing
ever looked like it it was an inverse
shooter um you created a place of home
where people can just relax and be
themselves uh and explore and the game
sold 10 million units right it's a kind
of a a huge indie darling success um but
when was the Beacon moment that you knew
it was working um you know you sold 10
million units over a period of time was
there a point in time when you had first
released it was it a month after 6
months after a year after where you were
like "This is working we have something
really special here." Um so I I knew
that uh obviously I didn't know the
success of it but I knew we had
something in the prototyping phase
because um the way that we prototype
stuff at Monami Park is we it's not a
vertical slice and it's not um like all
the features but gray boxed or whatever
we uh make a simplified version of the
game that we're trying to make like the
core loop and um and then we package it
almost as a as a game there's like a a
title screen and there's a an end point
and you can play it again and once we
had our version of that for Slime
Rancher very early on and it was fun and
people wanted to keep playing it and
they give you feedback of like I just
wish there was more slimes or I wish
there was more places to explore you
know like from here you're building on
bedrock and any features you add to it
you know like um I everyone makes games
differently so this is not judgment this
is my own terrible fears about
development i never want to be in the
situation of saying "I bet you when we
add crafting it gets fun i bet you when
you know or finding the fun," which is a
very common gamedev thing super fine to
do in my opinion when you're prototyping
uh when there's 12 people working on it
and collecting paychecks and you're
still like finding the fun to me that's
like nightmare scenario so like I never
want to be in that position i know
plenty of successful games have come out
and will come out this year that did
just that i've just I I can't do that um
because of the way that we run our
studio it's like every night I go to bed
and I think of there's 45 families well
technically 44 because I'm one of them
but but mine included 45 families like
tethered to Monami Park um and they're
their own families by the way we are not
a family as a studio that's creepy uh so
I I don't like that there's not 46
families there's just strictly only 45
yeah i I always like to think of Monami
Park as a uh as a town um where you know
uh a town is is nothing it's a it's a a
charter right at the end of the day and
then people show up and a bakery forms
and there's like really good croissants
there and then there's like a coffee
shop and a library and a awesome park
